servers.server_description: The Heroku Platform MCP Server enables seamless interaction with Heroku resources using Large Language Models (LLMs), providing a natural language interface for managing and automating Heroku applications and services.
servers.server_summary: The Heroku Platform MCP Server is a specialized Model Context Protocol (MCP) implementation designed to facilitate seamless interaction between large language models (LLMs) and the Heroku Platform. This server provides a robust set of tools and capabilities that enable LLMs to read, manage, and operate Heroku Platform resources.

tools.tool_description: Change the name of a Heroku application or resolve naming conflicts by providing the current app name and a unique new name. Validates availability and manages the renaming process.

app.description: The current name of the Heroku app you want to rename. This must be an existing app that you have access to.

newName.description: The new name you want to give to the app. Must be unique across all Heroku apps.

tools.tool_description: List and filter Heroku applications by ownership, collaboration, team, or private space. View app names, regions, and ownership details in JSON or text format for easy management.

all.description: When true, displays a comprehensive list including: (1) apps owned by the user and (2) apps where the user is a collaborator through direct access or team membership. When false or omitted, shows only owned apps.

json.description: Controls the output format. When true, returns a detailed JSON response containing app metadata such as generation, buildpacks, owner information, and region. When false or omitted, returns a simplified text format.

personal.description: Forces the tool to list applications from your personal account, even when you have a default team configured. When true, overrides any default team setting and shows only apps owned by your personal account. This is particularly useful when you work with multiple teams but need to specifically view your personal apps. When false or omitted, follows the default behavior of using the default team if one is set.

space.description: Filters the results to show only apps within a specific private space. Provide the private space name to filter. This parameter is mutually exclusive with the team parameter.

team.description: Filters the results to show only apps belonging to a specific team. Provide the team name to filter. This parameter is mutually exclusive with the space parameter.

tools.tool_description: List and filter Heroku add-ons across apps, retrieve detailed metadata in JSON, and view add-ons for specific apps using flexible filtering options.

all.description: Forces the tool to list all add-ons across all apps accessible to the user. When true, this flag: 1) Overrides any default app setting from Git remote configuration, 2) Ignores the app flag if provided, 3) Shows a comprehensive list including: app name, add-on name, service plan, billing status, and provisioning status for each add-on. When false or omitted, respects the default app setting and the app flag.

app.description: Specifies a single Heroku app whose add-ons you want to list. Important behaviors: 1) When provided, shows add-ons and attachments only for this specific app, 2) When omitted, falls back to the default app from Git remote if configured, 3) If no default app exists, lists add-ons for all accessible apps, 4) This flag is completely ignored when all=true. The response includes both provisioned add-ons and add-on attachments from other apps.

json.description: Controls the response format and detail level. When true, returns a structured JSON response containing: 1) Complete add-on metadata including ID, name, and creation timestamp, 2) Detailed plan information including tier and cost, 3) Configuration variables set by the add-on, 4) Attachment details if the add-on is shared with other apps, 5) Billing and compliance status information. When false or omitted, returns a human-readable text format with basic information.

tools.tool_description: Create a new Heroku application with customizable settings, including name, region, private space, or team association. Automatically generate app names if not specified and receive detailed app information upon creation.

app.description: Specifies the desired name for the new Heroku app. If omitted, Heroku will auto-generate a random name. Best practice: Provide a meaningful, unique name that reflects your application's purpose.

region.description: Determines the geographical region where your app will run. Options: "us" (United States) or "eu" (Europe). Defaults to "us" if not specified. Note: Cannot be used with space parameter.

space.description: Places the app in a specific private space, which provides enhanced security and networking features. Specify the private space name. Note: When used, the app inherits the region from the private space and the region parameter cannot be used.

team.description: Associates the app with a specific team for collaborative development and management. Provide the team name to set ownership. The app will be created under the team's account rather than your personal account.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve and filter application logs in real-time to monitor activity, debug issues, and analyze performance by dyno, process type, or source on Heroku MCP server applications.

app.description: Specifies the target Heroku app whose logs to retrieve. Requirements and behaviors: 1) App must exist and be accessible to you with appropriate permissions, 2) The response includes both system events and application output, 3) Currently it's only available to Cedar generation apps.

dynoName.description: Filter logs by specific dyno instance. Important behaviors: 1) Format is "process_type.instance_number" (e.g., "web.1", "worker.2"). 2) You cannot specify both dynoName and processType parameters together. Best practice: Use when debugging specific dyno behavior or performance issues.

processType.description: Filter logs by process type. Key characteristics: 1) Common values: "web" (web dynos), "worker" (background workers), 2) Shows logs from all instances of the specified process type, 3) You cannot specify both dynoName and processType parameters together. Best practice: Use when debugging issues specific to web or worker processes.

source.description: Filter logs by their origin. Key characteristics: 1) Common values: "app" (application logs), "heroku" (platform events), 2) When omitted, shows logs from all sources. Best practice: Use "app" for application debugging, "heroku" for platform troubleshooting.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve detailed information about a Heroku add-on, including plan state, billing details, and configuration. Supports identifiers like add-on ID, name, or attachment name, requiring app context for attachments.

addon.description: Identifies the add-on to retrieve information about. Accepts three types of identifiers: 1) Add-on ID (uuid format, works globally without app context), 2) Add-on name (e.g., "postgresql-curved-12345", works globally without app context), 3) Attachment name (e.g., "DATABASE", requires app context). Important behaviors: - When using attachment name, must provide app flag or have default app set, - Attachment name must be from the app where attached, not the provisioning app, - Add-on ID and unique names work with correct app context or without app context, - Must have access to the app where the add-on is either provisioned or attached.

app.description: Provides application context for finding the add-on. Affects how the addon parameter is interpreted: 1) When provided:    - Searches for the add-on only within this specific app,    - Enables use of attachment names in the addon parameter,    - Must have access to this app. 2) When omitted:    - First tries using default app from Git remote configuration,    - If no default app, addon parameter must be an ID or globally unique name,    - Cannot use attachment names without app context. Best practice: Always provide when using attachment names.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve detailed Heroku app information, including configuration, dynos, add-ons, buildpacks, collaborators, and domains. Input app name to access status and metadata in text or JSON format.

app.description: The name of the Heroku app to get information about. This must be an existing app that you have access to.

json.description: Controls the output format. When true, returns a detailed JSON response containing app metadata such as add-ons, dynos, buildpack configurations, collaborators, and domain information. When false or omitted, returns a simplified text format.

Build a Solana blockchain swap transaction using Jupiter's API. Input a quote response and user public key to generate a transaction for token swaps, with optional parameters for prioritization fees and legacy transaction format.
Execute Solana token swaps on Jupiter by sending swap transactions, including retries and preflight options, through the MCP Jupiter server.

servers.server_description: A bridge allowing Claude Desktop to access Telegram chats and messages via the Model Context Protocol, providing read-only capabilities to retrieve dialogs and messages from Telegram.
servers.server_summary: A bridge allowing Claude Desktop to access Telegram chats and messages via the Model Context Protocol, providing read-only capabilities to retrieve dialogs and messages from Telegram.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve messages from a Telegram dialog, chat, or channel, ordered newest to oldest. Filter unread messages or limit results to the latest entries for focused message management.

input_schema.description:
List messages in a given dialog, chat or channel. The messages are listed in order from newest to oldest.

If `unread` is set to `True`, only unread messages will be listed. Once a message is read, it will not be
listed again.

If `limit` is set, only the last `limit` messages will be listed. If `unread` is set, the limit will be
the minimum between the unread messages and the limit.
input_schema.title: ListMessages

tools.tool_description: Retrieve and organize available Telegram dialogs, chats, and channels. Filter results by archived status, pinned chats, or unread messages for streamlined chat management.

input_schema.description: List available dialogs, chats and channels.
input_schema.title: ListDialogs

servers.server_description: HAL is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides HTTP API capabilities to Large Language Models. It allows LLMs to make HTTP requests and interact with web APIs through a secure, controlled interface. HAL can also automatically generate tools from OpenAPI/Swagger specifications for seamless API integration.
servers.server_summary: HAL (HTTP API Layer) is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides HTTP API capabilities to Large Language Models.

tools.tool_description: Execute HTTP GET requests to specified URLs with header customization and secure secret substitution using HAL_SECRET_KEY environment variables.
Send HTTP POST requests to specified URLs with custom headers and body. Supports secret substitution using environment variables for secure API integrations within the HAL server.
Send HTTP PUT requests to specified URLs with optional headers and body content. Supports secret substitution in URLs, headers, and body using environment variables for secure data handling.

Perform HTTP PATCH requests to specified URLs with optional body and headers. Supports secret substitution using {secrets.key} syntax in URL, headers, and body for secure API interactions within the HAL (HTTP API Layer) environment.

Send HTTP DELETE requests to a specified URL with optional headers. Supports secret substitution in URLs and headers using HAL_SECRET_KEY environment variables for secure API interactions within the HAL (HTTP API Layer).
Retrieve HTTP headers from a specified URL without the response body. Supports custom headers and secret substitution using HAL_SECRET_KEY environment variables for secure API interactions.
Perform an HTTP OPTIONS request to a URL to retrieve supported methods and headers. Utilizes secret substitution with HAL_SECRET_KEY for secure inputs.
Retrieve available secret key names for the HAL HTTP API Layer. Safely lists keys without exposing sensitive values.

servers.server_summary: Provides seamless access to [Postman](https://www.postman.com/).

tools.tool_description: Generate a new environment in a Postman workspace, specifying environment variables and their details. Defaults to 'My Workspace' if no workspace is provided.

type.description: Variable type

tools.tool_description: Retrieve API, collection, or workspace elements tagged with a specific slug in Postman. Supports pagination, sorting, and filtering by entity type for precise results.

limit.description: Maximum number of results to return

tools.tool_description: Retrieve specific workspace details by providing the workspace ID and optional additional data to include in the response.

include.description: Additional data to include in response

tools.tool_description: Retrieve detailed information about a specific environment using its unique ID. Utilize this tool within the Postman MCP server to access and manage environment configurations effectively.
Create a duplicate environment in a specified workspace by forking an existing one, enabling efficient environment replication for testing or collaboration.
Modify specific variables or rename an existing environment in Postman by providing environment ID and updated details for efficient configuration management.
Retrieve a paginated list of environment forks by specifying an environment ID, including sorting and direction options for organized results.

limit.description: Number of results per page

tools.tool_description: Merge a forked environment back into its parent by specifying source, destination, and environment IDs. Supports optional deletion of the source environment post-merge.

deleteSource.description: Whether to delete the source environment after merging

servers.server_description: MCP Server for Shopify API, enabling interaction with store data through GraphQL API. This server provides tools for managing products, customers, orders, and more.
servers.server_summary: Shopify Update MCP Server

tools.tool_description: Retrieve specific products from Shopify using their unique IDs. Provide an array of product IDs to access detailed product information efficiently.

productIds.description: Array of product IDs to retrieve

tools.tool_description: Assign tags to a Shopify customer by specifying their ID and the tags to apply, enabling organized customer management and targeted actions.

tags.description: Tags to add to the customer

tools.tool_description: Retrieve products from Shopify Update MCP Server by title or fetch all products within a specified limit. Simplify product management and querying.

limit.description: Maximum number of products to return

searchTitle.description: Search title, if missing, will return all products

tools.tool_description: Retrieve products from a Shopify collection by specifying the collection ID. Define a limit to control the number of products returned. Streamlines product data access for targeted collections.

collectionId.description: ID of the collection to get products from

limit.description: Maximum number of products to return

tools.tool_description: Subscribe, find, or unsubscribe webhooks for the 'orders/updated' topic on Shopify. Manage webhook subscriptions using a callback URL and webhook ID for streamlined integration.
Modify product pricing across all variants by specifying the product ID and new price through the Shopify Update MCP Server.

price.description: Price of the product to update to

productId.description: ID of the product to update

tools.tool_description: Retrieve product variants in Shopify by specifying their IDs. Use this tool to fetch detailed variant information for inventory or catalog management.

variantIds.description: Array of variant IDs to retrieve

tools.tool_description: Retrieve Shopify customer data with pagination support, using a limit and next page cursor to manage large datasets efficiently.

limit.description: Limit of customers to return

servers.server_description: The Strava MCP Server enables interaction with the Strava API to retrieve and manage user activities and segments
servers.server_summary: A Model Context Protocol server that enables users to access Strava fitness data, including user activities, activity details, segments, and leaderboards through a structured API interface.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve detailed information about a specific Strava activity, including segment efforts if specified, using an activity ID. Simplifies access to fitness data via the Strava MCP Server.
Retrieves segment efforts for a specific Strava activity by providing the activity ID, enabling analysis of performance across route sections.
Retrieve authenticated user activities from Strava, filtered by timestamps and paginated for efficient data access. Use this tool to streamline activity tracking and analysis.

servers.server_description: This project provides a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server with tools to split OpenAPI specification files into multiple files or extract specific endpoints into a new file. It allows an MCP client (like an AI assistant) to manipulate OpenAPI specifications programmatically.
servers.server_summary: Unbundle OpenAPI Specs MCP

tools.tool_description: Divide a single OpenAPI specification file into multiple files for easier management and organization. Specify input file path and output directory to generate structured API documentation.

apiPath.description: Absolute path to the input OpenAPI definition file.

outputDir.description: Absolute path to the directory for split output files.

tools.tool_description: Extract and save specific endpoints from a large OpenAPI definition file to create a smaller, focused API specification.

endpointsToKeep.description: List of exact endpoint paths to keep (e.g., ['/users', '/users/{id}']).

inputApiPath.description: Absolute path to the large input OpenAPI definition file.

outputApiPath.description: Absolute path where the final, smaller bundled OpenAPI file should be saved.

servers.server_description: The YAPI Interface MCP Server allows you to fetch comprehensive details of YAPI interfaces by their ID for integration with AI development tools like Cursor and Claude Desktop.
servers.server_summary: A Model Context Protocol server that allows AI development tools like Cursor and Claude Desktop to retrieve detailed YAPI interface information by interface ID.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve detailed YAPI interface information by entering a numeric interface ID using the Model Context Protocol server for streamlined API development.

servers.server_description: There are two ways to run YindDao RPA:
servers.server_summary: A server implementing the Model Context Protocol (MCP) that connects YindDao AI Power with MCP Hosts, enabling AI to utilize RPA capabilities for workflow automation.

tools.tool_description: Execute RPA applications with specified parameters using the YindDao RPA MCP Server to automate workflows efficiently.
Retrieve paginated lists of RPA applications by filtering based on app ID, name, owner, or other criteria, enabling efficient management of automation workflows.
Upload files to the RPA platform by specifying robotUuid, enabling automation workflows within the YindDao RPA MCP Server.

servers.server_description: Official Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for HiveFlow. Connect your AI assistants (Claude, Cursor, etc.) directly to your HiveFlow automation platform.
servers.server_summary: Connects AI assistants (Claude, Cursor, etc.) directly to the HiveFlow automation platform, allowing them to create, manage, and execute automation flows through natural language commands.

tools.tool_description: Define and configure a new workflow on HiveFlow by specifying its name, description, and optional nodes, enabling streamlined automation through AI-assisted commands.
Retrieve and filter all user workflows by status and limit using the status parameter. Manage automation flows in the HiveFlow platform efficiently.

limit.description: LÃ­mite de resultados (opcional)

tools.tool_description: Retrieve detailed information about a specific automation flow by providing its unique flow ID using the HiveFlow MCP Server tool.
Run specific workflows by ID with optional inputs, enabling AI assistants on HiveFlow MCP Server to automate tasks through natural language commands.
Stop an active automation flow by specifying its ID, enabling users to temporarily halt ongoing processes within the HiveFlow platform for better control.
Resume paused automation workflows on the HiveFlow platform by specifying the flow ID, enabling continued execution of tasks without manual intervention.
Retrieve a list of configured MCP servers for HiveFlow to manage AI assistant integrations and automation workflows efficiently.

Register a new MCP server in HiveFlow by specifying a unique name, command, arguments, and description. Integrate AI assistants like Claude or Cursor to manage and execute automation flows through natural language commands.

servers.server_description: This is a TypeScript project that implements a Message Control Protocol (MCP) server for Mailmodo integration with Claude Desktop and other MCP supported client
servers.server_summary: The Mailmodo MCP server enables comprehensive email marketing management

tools.tool_description: Add contacts to a specified email list in Mailmodo with customizable user data such as name, address, company, and demographic details.

address1.description: Line 1 of the address of the user

address2.description: Line 2 of the address of the user

age.description: Age of the user in numbers

anniversary_date.description: Anniversary date (ISO format or UNIX timestamp)

birthday.description: Birthdate of the user (ISO format or UNIX timestamp)

phone.description: Primary phone number of the user

state.description: State, region or province of the user

tools.tool_description: Remove or suppress a contact's email from Mailmodo campaigns to ensure compliance with unsubscribe requests and maintain email list hygiene.
Trigger personalized email campaigns using a specific campaign ID and recipient email. Override subject, sender details, or reply-to address, and add dynamic personalization parameters.

addToList.description: Optional: List ID to which the contact should be added as part of triggering the campaign.

campaignId.description: Camapign id of the campaign to be triggered

campaign_data.description: Optional: Transient personalization parameters, not stored in the contact profile.

data.description: Optional: Personalization parameters saved to the contact's profile.

email.description: Email address of the contact to whom you want to send the email. This is required.

fromName.description: Optional: Overrides the sender name for the campaign.

replyTo.description: Optional: Overrides the default reply-to email address for the campaign.

subject.description: Optional: Overrides the default subject line provided when creating the campaign.

tools.tool_description: Generate detailed campaign reports, including open, click, and submission counts, by specifying campaign ID and date range. Use this tool to track and analyze email campaign performance.
Retrieve accurate current date and time for precise scheduling, logging, or timestamping tasks in Mailmodo workflows.
Track and send custom email events with specific properties to enhance user engagement and analytics using this MCP server tool.
Add multiple contacts to a specified list in one API call, including details like name, email, phone, address, and custom fields, for streamlined contact management.

address1.description: Line 1 of the address of the user

address2.description: Line 2 of the address of the user

age.description: Age of the user in numbers

anniversary_date.description: Anniversary date (ISO format or UNIX timestamp)

birthday.description: Birthdate of the user (ISO format or UNIX timestamp)

phone.description: Primary phone number of the user

state.description: State, region or province of the user

servers.server_summary: A Model Context Protocol server that enables AI assistants to interact with Feishu project management systems, allowing retrieval of project views and work items.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve a list of project views from Feishu by specifying the work item type, such as story, version, or issue, for streamlined project management insights.
Retrieve detailed information about specific work items, such as stories, versions, or issues, from Feishu project management systems to enhance project tracking and decision-making.
Retrieve metadata for work item types in Feishu project management. Understand field meanings and details in work item descriptions for types like story, version, and issue.

servers.server_description: A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Google Sheets API integration. Enables reading, writing, and managing Google Sheets documents directly from your MCP client (e.g., Claude Desktop).
servers.server_summary: Integrates with Google Cloud for authentication and project configuration, allowing access to Google Cloud resources using service account credentials.Enables reading, writing, and managing Google Sheets documents through a comprehensive set of tools including reading cell values, batch operations, appending rows, clearing cells, sheet management, and cell formatting capabilities.

tools.tool_description: Verify spreadsheet access permissions to determine allowed operations. Input the spreadsheet ID to retrieve detailed access information.

spreadsheetId.description: The ID of the spreadsheet to check access for

tools.tool_description: Retrieve values from a specific range in a Google Sheets spreadsheet using the spreadsheet ID, range, and optional parameters for major dimension and value rendering.

majorDimension.description: The major dimension of the values (default: ROWS)

range.description: The A1 notation range to retrieve (e.g., "Sheet1!A1:B10")

spreadsheetId.description: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL after /d/)

valueRenderOption.description: How values should be represented (default: FORMATTED_VALUE)

tools.tool_description: Retrieve values from multiple specified ranges in a Google Sheets spreadsheet using A1 notation, with options for major dimension and value representation.

majorDimension.description: The major dimension of the values (default: ROWS)

ranges.description: Array of A1 notation ranges to retrieve (e.g., ["Sheet1!A1:B10", "Sheet2!C1:D5"])

spreadsheetId.description: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL after /d/)

valueRenderOption.description: How values should be represented (default: FORMATTED_VALUE)

tools.tool_description: Retrieve metadata from Google Sheets, including sheet names, IDs, and properties, by providing the spreadsheet ID for efficient data management.

spreadsheetId.description: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL after /d/)

tools.tool_description: Update specific ranges in Google Sheets with a 2D array of values. Supports fixed or flexible ranges, ensuring accurate data insertion and row count alignment. Ideal for batch updates.

range.description: The A1 notation range to update. Use "Sheet1!A1:B10" for exact range (must match row count exactly) or "Sheet1!A1" for flexible range that auto-expands based on data. TIP: If updating multiple rows with varying content, use flexible range (e.g., "A42" instead of "A42:E53") to avoid row count mismatch errors.

spreadsheetId.description: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL after /d/)

valueInputOption.description: How the input data should be interpreted (default: USER_ENTERED)

values.description: A 2D array of values to update, where each inner array represents a row

tools.tool_description: Update multiple ranges in a Google Sheets spreadsheet with new values in one request. Specify spreadsheet ID, range-value pairs, and input interpretation (RAW or USER_ENTERED).

data.description: Array of range-value pairs to update

range.description: The A1 notation range to update

values.description: A 2D array of values for this range

spreadsheetId.description: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL after /d/)

valueInputOption.description: How the input data should be interpreted (default: USER_ENTERED)

tools.tool_description: Clear specified ranges of data in Google Sheets by defining the spreadsheet ID and A1 notation range. Simplify data management and maintain clean spreadsheets.

range.description: The A1 notation range to clear (e.g., "Sheet1!A1:B10")

spreadsheetId.description: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL after /d/)

servers.server_description: This is a Multi-Agent Collaboration Protocol (MCP) server for interacting with the Metricool API. It allows AI agents to access and analyze social media metrics, campaign data and schedule posts to your Metricool account.
servers.server_summary: The Metricool MCP Server allows AI agents to interact with the Metricool API to access, analyze, and manage social media metrics and content across multiple platforms

tools.tool_description: Schedule social media posts on Metricool at specified dates and times. Ensure compliance with platform-specific requirements like media, tags, and audience settings for consistent publishing.
Retrieve the list of brands from your Metricool account, including competitor data for Instagram, Facebook, Twitch, YouTube, Twitter, and Bluesky networks. Simplify brand management and analysis.
Retrieve Instagram Reels data from your Metricool account by specifying a date range and blog ID for analysis and reporting.
Retrieve Instagram posts from Metricool by specifying a date range and blog ID to analyze and manage your social media content effectively.
Retrieve Instagram Stories data from your Metricool account by specifying a date range and blog ID. Simplify analytics and insights gathering for better content strategy.
Retrieve TikTok video data from your Metricool account by specifying a date range and blog ID for detailed analytics and insights.
Retrieve Facebook Reels data from your Metricool account by specifying a date range and blog ID. Streamline content analysis and performance tracking.
Retrieve Facebook posts from your Metricool brand account within a specified date range. Provide the start date, end date, and blog ID to access the data.

servers.server_description: PDF.co MCP Server provides PDF.co API functionality through the Model Context Protocol (MCP), enabling AI assistants to easily perform various PDF processing tasks.
servers.server_summary: Provides PDF.co API functionality through the Model Context Protocol, enabling AI assistants to perform various PDF processing tasks like conversion, editing, searching, and security operations.

tools.tool_description: Convert PDFs and scanned images into editable text while preserving layout. Extract specific pages, define regions, and support OCR for scanned documents. Ideal for processing files from URLs or cloud storage.

api_key.description: PDF.co API key. If not provided, will use X_API_KEY environment variable. (Optional)
api_key.title: Api Key

httppassword.description: HTTP auth password if required to access source url. (Optional)
httppassword.title: Httppassword

httpusername.description: HTTP auth user name if required to access source url. (Optional)
httpusername.title: Httpusername

lang.description: Language for OCR for scanned documents. Default is 'eng'. See PDF.co docs for supported languages. (Optional, Default: 'eng')
lang.title: Lang

line_grouping.description: Enables line grouping within table cells when set to '1'. (Optional)
line_grouping.title: Line Grouping

name.description: File name for the generated output. (Optional)
name.title: Name

pages.description: Comma-separated page indices (e.g., '0, 1, 2-' or '1, 3-7'). Use '!' for inverted page numbers (e.g., '!0' for last page). Processes all pages if None. (Optional)
pages.title: Pages

unwrap.description: Unwrap lines into a single line within table cells when lineGrouping is enabled. Must be true or false. (Optional)
unwrap.title: Unwrap

url.description: URL to the source file. Supports publicly accessible links including Google Drive, Dropbox, PDF.co Built-In Files Storage. Use 'upload_file' tool to upload local files.
url.title: Url

servers.server_description: An MCP (Model Context Protocol) server implementation that integrates Claude - or any MCP compatible LLM if you're crafty - with Todoist, enabling natural language task management via MCP tools. The tools in this server allows Claude to interact with your Todoist tasks, projects, sections, and labels using everyday language, while also optimized for LLM workflow efficiency.
servers.server_summary: Integrates Claude with Todoist for natural language task management, supporting project and section organization, task creation, updating, completion, and deletion using everyday language.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve a specific personal label by its ID from Todoist to organize and manage tasks more effectively. Integrates with Todoist MCP Server for streamlined task automation.

label_id.description: ID of the label to retrieve

tools.tool_description: Update personal labels in Todoist by modifying their name, color, favorite status, or order. Use label ID or name to identify and apply changes individually or in batch.

is_favorite.description: Whether the label is a favorite (optional)

label_id.description: ID of the label to update

label_name.description: Name of the label to search for and update (if ID not provided)

labels.description: Array of labels to update (for batch operations)

is_favorite.description: Whether the label is a favorite (optional)

label_id.description: ID of the label to update (preferred)

label_name.description: Name of the label to search for and update (if ID not provided)

tools.tool_description: Modify Todoist tasks by updating details like content, due dates, labels, priority, or project location. Supports batch updates and uses task ID or name for identification.

assignee_id.description: New user ID to assign the task to (optional)

deadline_date.description: New deadline date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional)

due_date.description: New due date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional)

due_datetime.description: New due date and time in RFC3339 format (optional)

due_lang.description: 2-letter language code for due date parsing (optional)

due_string.description: New due date in natural language (optional)

duration.description: New duration amount of the task (optional)

labels.description: New array of label names for the task (optional)

project_id.description: Move task to this project ID (optional)

section_id.description: Move task to this section ID (optional)

task_id.description: ID of the task to update (preferred)

task_name.description: Name/content of the task to search for (if ID not provided)

tasks.description: Array of tasks to update (for batch operations)

assignee_id.description: New user ID to assign the task to (optional)

deadline_date.description: New deadline date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional)

due_date.description: New due date in YYYY-MM-DD format (optional)

due_datetime.description: New due date and time in RFC3339 format (optional)

due_lang.description: 2-letter language code for due date parsing (optional)

due_string.description: New due date in natural language (optional)

duration.description: New duration amount of the task (optional)

labels.description: New array of label names for the task (optional)

project_id.description: Move task to this project ID (optional)

section_id.description: Move task to this section ID (optional)

task_id.description: ID of the task to update (preferred)

task_name.description: Name/content of the task to search for (if ID not provided)

tools.tool_description: Remove a personal label in Todoist by specifying its ID, enabling efficient organization and cleanup of task labels within the platform.

label_id.description: ID of the label to delete

tools.tool_description: Retrieve shared labels from Todoist, excluding personal labels if specified. Use this tool to streamline label management within collaborative projects.

omit_personal.description: Whether to exclude the names of the user's personal labels from the results (default: false)

tools.tool_description: Remove tasks from Todoist using task IDs, names, or batch operations. Simplify task management by deleting specific or multiple tasks efficiently.

task_id.description: ID of the task to delete (preferred)

task_name.description: Name/content of the task to search for and delete (if ID not provided)

tasks.description: Array of tasks to delete (for batch operations)

task_id.description: ID of the task to delete (preferred)

task_name.description: Name/content of the task to search for and delete (if ID not provided)

tools.tool_description: Mark tasks as complete in Todoist using task ID or name, supporting single or batch operations for efficient task management. Integrates with the Todoist MCP Server for simplified workflow.

task_id.description: ID of the task to complete (preferred)

task_name.description: Name/content of the task to search for and complete (if ID not provided)

tasks.description: Array of tasks to mark as complete (for batch operations)

task_id.description: ID of the task to complete (preferred)

task_name.description: Name/content of the task to search for and complete (if ID not provided)

tools.tool_description: Retrieve sections from Todoist projects using project ID, name, or batch operations. Optionally include empty sections for comprehensive project organization and task management.

include_empty.description: Whether to include sections with no tasks

project_id.description: ID of the project to get sections from

project_name.description: Name of the project to get sections from (if ID not provided)

servers.server_description: The Peekaboo MCP server provides macOS screen capture and AI-powered image analysis for integration with AI assistants like Claude Desktop and Cursor IDE.
servers.server_summary: A macOS utility that captures screenshots and analyzes them with AI vision, enabling AI assistants to see and interpret what's on your screen.

tools.tool_description: Capture macOS screen content, target specific app windows or entire screens, and output as files or Base64 data. Optionally analyze images using AI models for insights.

input_schema.description: Captures screen content and optionally analyzes it. Targets entire screens, specific app windows, or all windows of an app (via `app_target`). Supports foreground/background capture. Output to file path or inline Base64 data (`format: "data"`). If a `question` is provided, an AI model analyzes the image. Window shadows/frames excluded.

app_target.description:
Optional. Specifies the capture target.
For example:
Omit or use an empty string (e.g., `''`) for all screens.
Use `'screen:INDEX'` (e.g., `'screen:0'`) for a specific display.
Use `'frontmost'` for all windows of the current foreground application.
Use `'AppName'` (e.g., `'Safari'`) for all windows of that application.
Use `'PID:PROCESS_ID'` (e.g., `'PID:663'`) to target a specific process by its PID.
Use `'AppName:WINDOW_TITLE:Title'` (e.g., `'TextEdit:WINDOW_TITLE:My Notes'`) for a window of 'AppName' matching that title.
Use `'AppName:WINDOW_INDEX:Index'` (e.g., `'Preview:WINDOW_INDEX:0'`) for a window of 'AppName' at that index.
Ensure components are correctly colon-separated.

capture_focus.description: Optional. Focus behavior. 'auto' (default): bring target to front only if not already active. 'background': capture without altering window focus. 'foreground': always bring target to front before capture.

format.description:
Optional. Output format.
Can be `'png'`, `'jpg'`, `'jpeg'` (alias for jpg), or `'data'`.
Format is case-insensitive (e.g., 'PNG', 'Png', 'png' are all valid).
If `'png'` or `'jpg'`, saves the image to the specified `path`.
If `'data'`, returns Base64 encoded PNG data inline in the response.
If `path` is also provided when `format` is `'data'`, the image is saved (as PNG) AND Base64 data is returned.
Defaults to `'data'` if `path` is not given.
Invalid format values automatically fall back to 'png'.

path.description:
Optional. Base absolute path for saving the image.
Relevant if `format` is `'png'`, `'jpg'`, or if `'data'` is used with the intention to also save the file.
If a `question` is provided and `path` is omitted, a temporary path is used for image capture, and this temporary file is deleted after analysis.

question.description:
Optional. If provided, the captured image will be analyzed by an AI model.
The server automatically selects an AI provider from the `PEEKABOO_AI_PROVIDERS` environment variable.
The analysis result (text) is included in the response.

tools.tool_description: Analyze stored image files to understand content, extract text, or answer questions using AI. Configure the tool to use specific AI models or rely on server defaults for tasks like object identification or OCR.

image_path.description: Required. Absolute path to image file (.png, .jpg, .webp) to be analyzed.

provider_config.description: Optional. Explicit provider/model. Validated against server's PEEKABOO_AI_PROVIDERS.

model.description: Optional. Model name. If omitted, uses model from server's PEEKABOO_AI_PROVIDERS for chosen provider, or an internal default for that provider.

type.description: AI provider, default: auto. 'auto' uses server's PEEKABOO_AI_PROVIDERS environment preference. Specific provider must be enabled in server's PEEKABOO_AI_PROVIDERS.

question.description: Required. Question for the AI about the image.

tools.tool_description: Retrieve system information on macOS, including running applications, specific app windows, or server status. Identify apps like 'Photoshop' or capture details of 'Notes' windows for automation tasks.

input_schema.description: Lists various system items, providing situational awareness. The `item_type` is optional and will be inferred if omitted (defaults to 'application_windows' if 'app' is provided, else 'running_applications'). App identifier uses fuzzy matching for convenience.

app.description: Required when `item_type` is `application_windows`. Specifies the target application by its name (e.g., "Safari", "TextEdit"), bundle ID, or process ID (e.g., "PID:663"). Fuzzy matching is used for names, so partial names may work.

include_window_details.description:
Optional, only applicable when `item_type` is `application_windows`. Specifies additional details to include for each window. Provide an array of strings. Example: `["bounds", "ids"]`.
- `ids`: Include window ID.
- `bounds`: Include window position and size (x, y, width, height).
- `off_screen`: Indicate if the window is currently off-screen.

item_type.description:
Specifies the type of items to list. If omitted or empty, it defaults to 'application_windows' if 'app' is provided, otherwise 'running_applications'. Valid options are:
- `running_applications`: Lists all currently running applications.
- `application_windows`: Lists open windows for a specific application. Requires the `app` parameter.
- `server_status`: Returns information about the Peekaboo MCP server.

Log technical decisions in AI development, including context, alternatives, and consequences, to maintain project clarity and track decision-making processes.

Context.description:
Context object providing access to MCP capabilities.

This provides a cleaner interface to MCP's RequestContext functionality.
It gets injected into tool and resource functions that request it via type hints.

To use context in a tool function, add a parameter with the Context type annotation:

```python
@server.tool()
def my_tool(x: int, ctx: Context) -> str:
    # Log messages to the client
    ctx.info(f"Processing {x}")
    ctx.debug("Debug info")
    ctx.warning("Warning message")
    ctx.error("Error message")

    # Report progress
    ctx.report_progress(50, 100)

    # Access resources
    data = ctx.read_resource("resource://data")

    # Get request info
    request_id = ctx.request_id
    client_id = ctx.client_id

    return str(x)
```

The context parameter name can be anything as long as it's annotated with Context.
The context is optional - tools that don't need it can omit the parameter.
Context.title: Context

tools.tool_description: Retrieve detailed specifications and metadata for a specific AI model by providing its ID, enabling informed selection and usage through OpenRouter MCP Server.
